The '''Polish American Congress''' (PAC) is a [[U.S.]] [[umbrella organization]] of [[Polish-American]]s and Polish-American organizations. Its membership is composed of fraternal, educational, veterans, religious, cultural, social, business, and political organizations, as well as individuals.
As of January 2009, it lists 20 national organizations as members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polamcon.org/org/organizations.htm|title=National Member Organizations|accessdate=11 January 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> It is sub-divided into 41 divisions and chapters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polamcon.org/state/a_divs.htm|title=Directory of State Divisions|accessdate=11 January 2009 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080801192530/http://www.polamcon.org/state/a_divs.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 1 August 2008}}</ref> Traditionally, the PAC National President has also been the president of the largest Polish American fraternal organization, the [[Polish National Alliance]] (PNA).
==Formation during World War II==
In response to the threat to Poland's freedom caused by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] and [[Nazi Germany|German]] aggression, a large Congress of [[Polish diaspora|Polonia]] met in [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], [[New York (state)|New York]], from May 28 to June 1, 1944. Composed of roughly 2,600 delegates representing Polish and Polish-American organizations, the Congress created the PAC, defining its goal of a free Poland and underscoring its support for the US war effort against the [[Axis powers]].<ref name=PAChist4480>{{cite web|url=http://www.polamcon.org/history/history1.htm|title=MILESTONES IN THE STORY OF THE POLISH AMERICAN CONGRESS The First Fifty Years - Part 1: 1944-1980|accessdate=February 2009}}</ref> The PAC incorporated<ref name="Bukowczyk">Bukowczyk, John J. (2006) ''Polish Americans and Their History'' University of Pittsburgh Press, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=w_5GxALhzFUC&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142 p. 142], ISBN 978-0-8229-5960-1</ref> the two former Polish umbrella organizations in the United States, the moderate<ref name="Bukowczyk"/> Polish American Council founded in 1939 and the right-wing<ref name="Thernstrom">Thernstrom, Stephan (ed.) (1980) ''Harvard Encyclopedia of American Ethnic Groups'' Belknap Press of Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=npQ6Hd3G4kgC&pg=PA800&lpg=PA800 p. 800], ISBN 0-674-37512-2</ref> National Committee of Americans of Polish Descent founded in 1941. The other umbrella organization, the left-leaning<ref name="Bukowczyk"/> American Slav Congress, remained independent.<ref name="Bukowczyk"/>
==Leadership==
The Congress elected [[Karol Rozmarek]] as the first president of the PAC.<ref name=PAChist4480 /> He was succeeded in 1968 by [[Aloysius Mazewski]], who served until his death in 1988.<ref name=PAChist4480 /> Under Mazewski, [[Leonard F. Walentynowicz]] served as executive director of the PAC for a number of years.<ref>[http://www.isledegrande.com/deaths2005.htm Grand Island, NY Deaths 2005]</ref> [[Edward Moskal]] was elected president in 1988, and he, too, served as president for the remainder of his life.<ref name=PAChist8194>{{cite web|url=http://www.polamcon.org/history/history2.htm|title=MILESTONES IN THE STORY OF THE POLISH AMERICAN CONGRESS: The First Fifty Years Part 2: 1981 - 1994.|accessdate=February 2009}}</ref><ref name="Canons">{{cite web|url=http://canons-regular.org/uploads/documents/ViaSacra082005.pdf|title=Via Sacria, March 2005|accessdate=January 2009}}</ref> Its present president is [[Frank J. Spula]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polamcon.org/org/officers.htm|title=National Officers| publisher=Polish American Congress|accessdate=11 January 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
